pros: Environment, people, mobility, vacation, time off
cons: Pay, comps, office, people, no bonus

job_title: Division Office Coordinator in Bloomfield, NJ
cons: Compensation is far below market value.

pros: Very good place if you want to get to know the students and have a meaningful experience with them. Faculty have some input into decision making. Career potential is good since there is much mentoring for faculty as they move toward tenure.
cons: As with most educational institutions right now, money is tight because enrollments are declining due to the effect of COVID. Most folks are a bit overworked because of this. Large upper management turnover in the last few years which can breed uncertainty.

pros: It has a good game design program
cons: It's kind of in the red right now.

The students and size of the college

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Belleville, NJ
pros: The college has small classroom settings.
cons: i dont have any cons about this college.

review_title: Wonderful coworkers and employees on campus.  Pay is very low and quite bad to be honest.
pros: Some of the nicest people I have ever worked with.  Small departments create a very family like atmosphere not only within your department, but with the rest of the departments and employees on campus.  Everyone pretty much knows one another.  Fridays off during the summer.
cons: The pay is very low.  Very low for higher education.  Very low for a professional job in NJ, period.  Even though you have the option to enroll in health insurance benefits as an employee, the premiums are quite high mostly likely due to the small number of staff and faculty enrolled and able to be enrolled in a group policy because it is a small college.  Low pay + high health insurance in NJ = double negative.

pros: Lots of time off,  nice office, nice area, free lunch, easy hours.
cons: Everything else! Bad pay, lazy staff, awful customer service, students are treated like a number or another tuition payment. All focus is on profit, no desire to aspire for more or have innovative ideas, professors don't care about students, students are rude and not interesting in advancing, lots of turnover, budget cuts galore. Just awful management overall. They lie in interviews to make it seem like a wonderful place and then once you start working, reality sets in.

pros: Very kind people across the university. Leaving 3 stars because I love Bloomfield, I fully support affordable education, and I met some great staff and faculty who truly care about their field and academia. Also incredible 401(k) match.
cons: The ITPS department in particular is extremely corrupt. Again there are some good people, and then some unprofessional people driven by money and lies. There are others across the organization who know about the issues but choose to ignore them. Long hours with little to no pay. They will take advantage of you.

job_title: Computer Science Tutor in Bloomfield, NJ
pros: It has been very convenient because as a student that commutes, I end up with time between classes where I'm on campus anyway. So it's nice because I can go to the computer science lounge, open up the computer lab for other students, and help them out with programming homework—all of which is pretty laid back for me.
cons: The thing about being a tutor is that sometimes you get students that have homework but aren't actually interested in learning. Also, unfortunately, the pay is very low.

review_title: Working in the bookstore was an okay experience, but I wouldn't go back.

pros:

-Ability to see how much books cost and manage your schedule because you have access to that info
cons:

-The manager had seniority so the people that has been there the longest get the most hours
-Min Wage pay

review_title: As a theater manager, my passion to take advantage of creative opportunities is supported by campus administrators.
pros: Small campus environment makes it easier to interact with students; campus in the midst of refreshing/renewing brand so exciting opportunities exist to be bold and proactive
cons: Finding money to forward any campaigns becomes challenging, but not impossible.
